entry.title: SAP 分析云 – 使用故事模版的最佳实践
entry.content:
本文系“仪表盘设计最佳实践”博客系列之一，旨在协助用户借助 SAP 分析云设计并构建具有业务价值的仪表盘。   

 请点击此处，在新窗口中打开“仪表盘设计最佳实践”博客系列总览页。 

博客内容   

本文将详细说明以下内容：   

  1. 模板获取位置；   
  2. 模板自定义的分步操作指南；   
  3. 从零开始构建逻辑组的分步说明。 

在哪里查找模板？ 

请在此博客中查阅有关该 Horizon 模板的全部信息。

下方展示的是仅通过数次点击、利用该模板快速生成的示例故事。 

下一章节将为您详细说明如何对模板进行定制，以便迅速达成您的预期目标。 

模板自定义   

以下为分步操作指引，帮助您完成以下任务：   

  1. 向占位符添加内容；   
  2. 移除占位符并删除相应区段或微件；   
  3. 调整页面内容。 

1.向占位符添加内容；   

选中占位符中的按钮，在随后弹出的对话框内选择您想要使用的模型。 

添加所需的度量和维度。 

每个占位符均已预设特定统计图类型，但您仍可在“生成器”面板中按需更改。 

2. 移除占位符并删除区段或微件 

如需移除占位符，请先选中该占位符，点击右上角“···”图标，然后在上下文菜单中选择“删除”。由于底层采用自适应容器结构，其余内容将自动调整布局。 

如需删除模板中的整个区段，亦可通过“大纲”面板执行删除操作；删除后，布局将自动适配调整。 

3. 添加页面内容   

可通过多种方式向页面补充内容，最简单的方法是复制并粘贴现有内容，随后按需调整。 

分步示例：在逻辑组中复制并粘贴单个统计图   

  • 在“大纲”中，选中包含待复制统计图的面板。 

  • 使用快捷键（Windows 按 Ctrl + C，Mac 按 Command + C）或工具栏中的“复制”功能完成复制。随后，在“大纲”中选中您希望粘贴内容的目标区块。 
  • 粘贴时，请使用快捷键（Windows 按 Ctrl + V，Mac 按 Command + V）或工具栏中的“粘贴”功能。   

内容添加完毕后，您可在生成器或样式设置面板中对其进行进一步调整。 

示例 2：   

分步说明：复制现有逻辑组   

  • 选中包含待复制逻辑组的面板，随后按照示例 1 所述方法执行复制操作。 

  • 选中您希望粘贴该逻辑组的区块，随后按照示例 1 所述方法执行粘贴操作。 

FlowLayoutPanel 会自动将新增的逻辑组向下排列。请注意：在同一层级的各个区块中，页面上的实际显示顺序为自上而下，但在“大纲”中的排列顺序则相反——即页面上位于最上方的内容，在大纲结构中显示在最下方。 

从零开始构建逻辑组 

步骤 1：创建新故事   

  • 登录您的 SAP Analytics Cloud 租户，选择“画布”。 

步骤 2：向页面添加面板   

  • 在工具栏中，依次选择“添加”按钮 > “容器” > “面板”。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将尺寸与位置参数设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = 100%  、高度 = 400px 、左侧 = 0px 、右侧 = auto 、顶部 = 0px 、底部 = auto 

步骤 3：在现有面板中添加卡片面板   

  • 在第一层面板内再添加一块面板。   
  • 若需为此面板应用 Fiori Horizon 主题，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”处输入 card。  
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto 、高度 = auto 、左侧 = 16px 、右侧 = 16px 、顶部 = 16px 、底部 = 8px 

步骤 4：添加逻辑组标题面板   

  • 在上一步所建面板内再添加一块新面板，用于承载标题文本。   
  • 若需呈现视觉分隔效果，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”字段中输入 logic-group__header。   
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = 48px  、左侧 = 0px  、右侧 = 0px  、顶部 = 0px  、底部 = auto   
  • 圆角半径设为 0px。 

步骤 5：向标题面板添加文本元素   

  • 选择“文本”并输入逻辑组名称。若需为标题文本应用 Fiori Horizon 主题，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”字段中输入 logic-group__title。   
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = auto  、左侧 = 16px  、右侧 = 自定义  、顶部 = 10px  、底部 = 0px 

步骤 6：添加流式布局面板   

  • 选中 Panel_2，依次选择“容器” > “流式布局面板”。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将流式布局面板的尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = auto  、左侧 = 16px  、右侧 = 16px  、顶部 = 58px  、底部 = 8px 

步骤 7：添加统计图微件   

  • 在流式布局面板中插入一个统计图微件。 

  • 选择统计图类型，并为统计图定义所需的度量与维度。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = 50%  、高度 = 100% 

步骤 8：复制并粘贴统计图微件   

  • 选中需复制的统计图，使用工具栏中的“复制”功能，或按快捷键（Windows：Ctrl + C；Mac：Command + C）。 

  • 选中您希望粘贴统计图的流式布局面板。 

  • 请使用工具栏中的“粘贴”功能，或通过快捷键（Windows：Ctrl + V；Mac：Command + V）完成粘贴。 

  • 请再次选择统计图类型，并设定所需的度量与维度。 

若您需构建一个包含两个统计图微件的逻辑组，至此即可完成。 

如需在逻辑组中继续添加更多统计图，请重复上述步骤，并根据需要调整每张统计图的宽度。例如，若需并排展示三张统计图，请将每张统计图的宽度均设为 33%。 

结果 

恭喜！至此，您的逻辑组应已呈现类似下图所示的效果。 

 

原文作者：Marc 

原文链接：https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-analytics-cloud-templates-best-practices/ba-p/14033472

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP SuccessFactors, as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, we’ll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start.

Here are the links to the other posts in the series published so far:

  • Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad (generally available innovations).
  • Part 3: Beta AI Innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Part 4: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More).
  • Part 5: SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass.
  • Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur.
  • Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile.

Before we get started: if you haven’t already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q1/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q2 2025.
  • SAP Sapphire Innovation Guide – SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we’ll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule stand-alone: Joule for Consultants
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Joule Agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 1: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule “Show me sales commission by agend for model bike sales”, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 1, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 1 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as “What is the total revenue for Q1?” or “Show me sales by region in 2025”.
  • Comparative analysis, such as “Compare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?”
  • Time series analysis, such as “Show me sales by month” or “Show the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months”.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as “Show me top 5 sales by store” or “List the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales”.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 2 shows what this looks like.

 

Figure 2: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking “How many languages does Joule support”. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with “Joule currently supports eleven language officially” and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document “Joule Multi Language Support” is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button “+ New Conversation” at the top, followed by a section “Active” with two conversations and a sectin “Expired” with four. The bottom contains a link to “Settings” and on to “AI Notice”.

You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on “New Conversation”. The old conversation will be listed in the “Active” section, as you can see in Figure 2. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the “Expired” section, as shown in Figure 2. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 3 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

Joule Stand-alone – Joule for Consultants

In addition to providing Joule embedded in our products, we have a design pattern called Joule stand-alone, which we use for Joule for Consultants. With this pattern, Joule can be started directly, without first opening an SAP product and then opening Joule via the icon in the shell header. Joule stand-alone is opened in full screen, as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4: Joule for Consultants using the Joule stand-alone pattern. Alt-Text: Joule full-screen, with one active conversation “Can you explaine about SAP Clean Core”, followed by a comprehensive answer, and scrolling options for reading the entire text”.

By supporting this pattern, people can open up Joule for Consultants directly and start asking questions about implementing or extending SAP products. Since in this case Joule is stand-alone, as the name suggests, the conversations you have there are not visible in the Joule instance that is embedded in our products, and vice-versa.

Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams

How often have you been in a chat with a colleague and needed to find some information from an SAP system? Up until now this would involve you leaving the chat, going to a different window and navigating to the right SAP application to get what were looking for.

Now, you can chat directly with Joule in Microsoft Teams, use Joule in Microsoft Teams and Microsoft Teams Mobile as an app, and ask Joule questions directly in Microsoft 365 Copilot. To get an idea of how powerful this is, watch this video:

To get started, have a look at the documentation:

  • Integrating Joule with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren’t Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well… the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly, or embedded within applications. These four marketing videos show you examples of agents available today:

  • Finance: Dispute Resolution Agent (1:38 minutes)
  • Procurement: Sourcing Agent (1:48 minutes)
  • Sales and services: Account Planning Agent (1:24 minutes)
  • Human Resources: Performance and Goals Agent (1:34 minutes)

This example for customer service agents goes into more detail:

  • CX Agents (in SAP Discovery Center).

For a general overview of Joule Agents, have a look here:

  • Joule Agents on sap.com.
  • AI Agents in Action (blog post).
  • Envision the Future of Generative AI with SAP's AI Agents (blog post).
  • How SAP’s AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation (blog post by Philipp Herzig).

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, our products provide a large number of Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, as well as a handful of the new agents discussed above. For a comprehensive overview of Joule capabilities, including product-specific skills available today, here’s where to go:

  • Joule Capabilities (a 484 page (!) PDF document from July 11th, 2025, including a list of What’s New)
  • Joule Capabilities (online documentation)

Customer-specific Joule skills

You can now build your own Joule skills using Joule Studio, which has now been made generally available. Read Michael Ameling’s overview blog post:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation

Joule on Mobile Devices – now for SAP SuccessFactors too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like requesting time off, updating contact information, and even deleting phone numbers, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can assign team goals.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, HR guidelines, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.

Figure 5 shows two examples of the transactional pattern plus one example of the informational pattern (“Can I use my private car for my business trip?”).

 

Figure 5: Examples of Joule on the SuccessFactors Mobile App. Alt Text: The image shows three examples: The first shows the response to the request by a manager “View time off approval”, with the details of one request, including the employee's name, the time-off period, and the type of time-off (vacation). The user can view the details, approve, or decline the request. The second screen shows a conversation where the user asks if they can use their private car for a business trip, and the system responds that they can, providing details on the reimbursement policy. The third screen shows the user requesting one day of vacation leave on March 3, 2025. The system confirms the request and provides the details of the leave, including the start and end times, and the date the user will return to work.

Find out more here:

  • Say Hi to Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile, Powered by SAP Build - Part 1: Unlocking AI for HR)
  • Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile: Getting Things Done with AI...
  • Documentation: Joule Available in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile - May 2025

Further information on Joule

If you want an overview of what’s new, or want to set up Joule in your landscape, have a look at the documentation:

  • Joule documentation (including What’s New, What is Joule?, integration guide)
  • What is Joule? PDF file

For an overview of what is planned, have a look at the road map for Joule in the SAP Road Map Explorer:

  • Joule Road Map.

 

SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone users and administrators benefit from these recent innovations:

  • New Side navigation for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.
  • SAPUI5 version preview.
  • Mobile Start supports Work Zone, advanced edition.

New Side Navigation

As I announced in April, in my blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), we are introducing some design updates to all our products in the SAP Business Suite to further increase consistency, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises. One of these is the introduction of a navigation menu on the left side of the screen.

SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, is the first product to support this new design. Figure 6 shows what it looks like when the navigation menu is expanded, while Figure 7 shows it collapsed.

Figure 6: Side navigation expanded for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: A screen showing a SAP Build Work Zone screen with a navigation menu on the left with four entries “Central Procurement”, “Global Support”, “My IT Experience” (selected), and “Self Services”. On the right various cards are shown in a section “Employee Information”.

 

Figure 7: Side navigation collapsed for SAP Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: similar to Figure 6, but with the navigation menu on the left collapsed to the width of an icon, with four icons shown representing the four navigation options.

SAPUI5 Version Preview

We have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone, two weeks before they are adopted in the productive environment.  Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, administrators can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

When looking at the sites in the site directory, those sites for which the preview is switched on are indicated clearly, as shown in Figure X.

Figure 8: Site directory with a site where preview is turned on. Alt Text: the image shows a card from the site directory for a site called “Preview SAPUI5 Demo” with a green badge containing the text “SAPUI5 Preview Enabled”.

Read more about this feature in this blog post:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

SAP Mobile Start Supports SAP Work Zone, Advanced Edition

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your Workspaces or Feed Updates. As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. 

Tasks and Notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, are also integrated into SAP Mobile Start: they are shown next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center. Figure 9 shows an example with notifications from the advanced edition.

This integration is automatically available to customers with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition or SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone if the SAP Mobile Start toggle is enabled in the Site Manager.

Figure 9: SAP Mobile Start notification center with notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Alt Text: A list of two notifications: “Leave Request”, with a red text “Important” and “2 weeks ago”, and “Invite to Worskpace”, with text “Mustaq Ahmmed has invited you to join the workspace “Help & Support Workspace” and “2 weeks ago”.

 

Note that SAP Mobile Start is not the successor app for the SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app. Find out more here:

  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.

 

SAP Mobile Start

Updated August 13th with information about the 2.4 release.

Beyond providing Joule natively for mobile devices, SAP Mobile Start has recently introduced a number of user experience improvements with their 2.2 and 2.3 releases. In addition to supporting SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, as described above, the main new features are:

  • Completed To-Dos are now displayed too (see Figure 10).
  • Site Switch allows you to directly switch between SAP Build Work Zone sites, without having to go through the onboarding process for each site.
  • The news tile can now also include images (see Figure 10).
  • News feeds that require authentication are supported now.
  • Design updates such as enhanced navigation bar for Apple iPad and a new fresher design for monitoring details on Apple Watch.
  • SAP Document AI integration.
  • Onboarding via deep links.
  • Top news, which gets shown prominently on the start screen.
  • Additional text with sensitive content can now be shown in notifications.

Figure 10: On the left, SAP Mobile Start showing completed To-Dos, on the right showing news with an image. Alt Text: On the left, the To-Dos section is selected, showing two To-Do cards, and the top half of a third card. The first one shows Maria Smith requested 180 days maternity leave, the second one that Quality Manager Donna Moore requested €47,600 spend. The right shows the start page, with a section Monitoring apps at the top, with two cards, followed by the News section, with one card listing two news items, the first of which has an image.

To find out more about the above recent innovations as well as what is planned in our road map, have a look at:

  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start V2.4: SAP Document AI integration and much more. Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start Road Map.

Continue Reading

I hope you enjoyed this first part, covering cross-product UX services. Here's a link to part 2, covering a large number of UX innovations which are generally available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori launchpad:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad.

entry.title: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?
entry.content:
The 2508 release of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition introduces a range of new delivered and beta features, along with UX enhancements designed to elevate your overall experience. In this blog, I’ll walk you through these updates and what they mean for you. 

My Home offers immediate access to key business insights, supports efficient management of tasks and situations, and allows you to organize your favorite pages and apps to streamline daily operations. The 2508 release builds on this foundation by further enhancing each of these areas. 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release My Home

 

One of the standout additions is the new personalized salutation bar, which greets every business user upon entering My Home. This feature not only creates a more personalized experience but also helps users quickly orient themselves within SAP S/4HANA. Now enable communication scenario SAP_COM_0887 and let business users see what’s next on their calendar at a glance. Additionally, the salutation bar consolidates all of My Home’s global actions in one convenient place—it enables users to easily add content, quickly access My Home settings, and discover the latest feature introduced in the 2508 release: Recap. 

My Home 2508 Salutation bar

 

The Recap feature introduced in the My Home 2508 release is designed to save time by helping business users stay on top of key items that have emerged since their last login. It highlights high-priority information, enabling users to quickly focus on what matters most. By surfacing relevant updates and simplifying daily tasks, Recap reduces manual effort and helps users catch up efficiently—so they can shift their attention to higher-value activities. 

My Home 2508 Recap of Tasks

 

 My Home 2508 Recap of Insights

 

Recap analyzes changes in My Home data over the past 24 hours, keeping business users informed about new tasks, situations, and updates to app, tile, and insights card access. It also provides visual comparisons of insights cards, making it easy to quickly and intuitively understand what has changed during your absence. 

The Salutation Bar also allows business users to easily add content to My Home from a centralized location. But that’s just the beginning—it now supports AI-assisted content addition, enabling users to add Insights cards using natural language. Users can also preview Insights cards during the addition process to ensure data accuracy and consistency. 

My Home 2508 AI-assisted Smart Personalization Insights Card Addition

With the 2508 release, business users can take advantage of a new Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition feature that enables the addition of applications using natural language. This significantly streamlines the process of adding applications, saving time and offering a more intuitive, click-efficient experience— which is particularly valuable for first-time or occasional users. The feature also enhances transparency by displaying application descriptions and real-time KPIs for dynamic tiles, providing immediate operational context. 

My Home 2508 Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition

My Home serves as the central hub for all your tasks, applications, and information. In the 2508 release, improvements have been made with the Recap and AI-assisted content addition features. Additionally, administrators are now empowered to deliver timely, targeted updates directly to business users via the My Home centralized news feed. 

With the addition of the Mange News application, administrators can create news articles to be displayed on My Home. They can categorize, target and manage the visibility of the news. Tailoring communication to your organization needs helps create a more informed and connected workforce. This in turn enhances business users’s performance by equipping them with the information needed to make smarter, faster decisions. 

My Home Manage News Application

 

 

My Home 2508 News Article Creation

 

My Home 2508 Critical News Article

We hope everyone enjoys the new features of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release – stay tuned for more updates! The Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition in My Home, highlighted in this article, are now available for Beta Testing with the 2508 release. At SAP, we’re committed to delivering the best experience possible, which is why we’re inviting you to join our Beta Testing Program. By participating, you’ll get early access to these features, have the chance to share your feedback, and help us fine-tune them before the official launch. Your input will play a key role in shaping the quality and usability of these new capabilities. 

Also, If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality.

(Open to SAP Cloud ERP customers, including partners running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.)

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
entry.content:
This second post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and the SAP Fiori launchpad which are now generally available. It covers Joule and many AI-assisted UX innovations, new collaboration capabilities as well as improvements in details. The next post will cover additional innovations available to customers for beta testing.

Users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can query SAP Analytics Cloud directly via Joule. Read about this and more in the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

This post gives an overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition UX innovations in these areas:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency
  • My Home
  • AI-Assisted UX Features
  • Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams
  • UX Improvements in Details

Many of the UX improvements in details are enabled by our UI framework (SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements) and hence also available to customers and partners developing their own applications. Note however that the enabled AI-assisted features are only available for extensions built directly on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.

Below you’ll see those AI innovations with largest impact on user experience, but you can get a more comprehensive overview of the latest AI innovations in these blog posts:

  • Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release.
  • Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 (covering the AI-assisted features enabled by our UI framework).

 

SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency

We have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we’ll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations, and some updates for launchpad administrators:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design
  • Update for administrators

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 1. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry “All Spaces” at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the “Favourite App” eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder “Insights” for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar – need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case “S/4HANA Cloud” as you can see at the top of Figure 1. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (i.e. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments – in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature “/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE”, which is planned to become available mid-August 2025.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 2 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the “Sign Out” option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

Figure 2: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group “Last Month”, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a “more” link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 2  fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and provides simplier interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by “Today”, “Yesterday”, “Last Week”, “Last Month”. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 3 shows two examples – one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing “search”. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Hiding of Empty Spaces and Pages

Empty Spaces and Pages are now automatically hidden from users. Until now this was an option which administrators needed to switch on, now it is on by default.

You might be asking how a space or page could be empty? The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user’s authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty.

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps “Manage Launchpad Spaces” and “Manage Launchpad Pages” distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab “Customer-Created”, the others in the tab “Predefined”.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as “Customer-Created” in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became “Predefined” there, i.e. it was not listed under “Customer-Created” despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app “Manage Launchpad Pages”, the tabs are called “Pages” and “Page Templates”, as shown in Figure 4. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 4: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for “Pages” and “Page Templates”. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

For more information about the visual updates, and what’s new, check out:

  • Blog post: Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System updates.
  • What’s New: SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

My Home

My Home is proving very popular with users, and we hope to make it even more so with the innovations in the 2508 release:

  • The salutation bar, welcoming users and providing interesting options.
  • Recap – summarizing what changed since you last logged on.
  • Manage News application for customer-specific news.
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insights cards
    (this is covered in the next section AI-Assisted UX Innovations)

We are also providing two new features for beta-testing, AI-assisted smart personalization for applications and AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home, which I will showcase in part 3 in this series of blog posts.

Salutation Bar in My Home

The new salutation bar shown in Figure 5 welcomes users to the system, and gives them direct access to My Home settings as well as to the new Recap feature explained below. Optionally, you can set the system up to let business users see what’s next on their calendar. (Not shown in Figure 5. Use communication arrangement SAP_COM_0887 to set enable it).

Figure 5: The new salutation bar in My Home, showing the welcome text “Hi Barbara, Great to see you again!” and the beta AI option “Add Content”, plus the options “Recap” and “My Home Settings”. Alt Text: Image shows My Home with a new dark. Blue bar just below the header, with today’s date top left, below which in larger font “Hi Barbara, Great to see you again!” is written. On the right of the bar three buttons are shown: the AI button “Add Content”, “Recap”, and “My Home Settings”.

Recap

With the new recap feature, you can get a quick overview of what has changed on My Home in the last 24 or more hours: new or processed tasks, situations, apps and insight cards. It compares your current My Home data against a snapshot of data captured from your last login that was over 24 hours ago. It shows you what has changed or been added within that timeframe. This saves you a lot of time, since you don’t have to scan everything manually, and ensures that you are all caught up quickly – and don’t miss any important changes. What is great about it is that it is visual, showing before and after images of insight cards – you can see an example in Figure 6, or watch it in action in this video:

  • Video: Recap Feature of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (0:55 min.)

Figure 6: Recap in My Home, showing a change in an insight card, where one additional quotation has expired, and one additional quotation will expire after a week. Alt Text: a popover on top of My Home, with a “Summary” section on the left containing three items “Tasks”, “Situations”, and “Cards”, with “Cards” selected. The right shows two tabs, “Changed (3)” (selected) and “Removed (2)”, below which a card marked “old” with a horizontal bar chart is shown on the left, and the same card with updated data marked “new” on the right.

Manage News Application

I’m glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 7 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users or roles.

Figure 7: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status “published” and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?.
  • Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release.
  • My Home documentation.

 

AI-Assisted User Experience

When AI is embedded directly into the application UI to give users a better user experience, as opposed to being accessed via the Joule window, we talk about “AI-Assisted User Experience”.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, we distinguish between AI base features and premium features:

  • Base features are free of charge, and only require that the customer signs the SAP AI Terms, which can be done via this link.
  • Premium features require SAP AI Units to be in place. Those listed here also require Joule Premium for Financial Management. Customers can activate this via SAP for Me -> Portfolio & Products -> Business AI.

The following are now generally available as base features:

  • AI-assisted enterprise search (which was in beta testing with the 2502 release). See below for more details.
  • AI-assisted easy filter.
  • AI-assisted smart summarization.

The latter two were generally available under limited promotion with the 2502 release, now they are generally available out of the box – no need to sign up to the limited promotion. To find out more about them, look at these blog posts:

  • SAP UX Q1/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
  • AI-assisted easy filter enhancements with 2508: Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

The following premium feature is now generally available:

  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards.
    See below for more details.

AI-Assisted Enterprise Search

You can now use natural language in the search field available at the top of every screen in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, making it even easier to benefit from powerful enterprise search capabilities. With enterprise search, you can find the information you need directly, without having to specify the name of the application – as you can see in Figure 8. This is available out of the box as a base feature.

Figure 8: AI-assisted enterprise search, showing how you can easily find business data directly using natural language. Alt Text: A short video showing how a user can enter in the search field in the shell header bar “Show me all sales orders with net value greater than 5000 eur” and get a corresponding list sales orders. The user than adds the text “that are in process” resulting in a list with fewer results.

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insight Cards

With this premium feature, you can now use natural language to add an insight card to My Home. You just have to describe what information you want to see on the card, and the system will create the card for you. We ensure that the user is in control by first showing a preview of the card, allowing the user to either confirm, or rephrase the request. Figure 9 shows the kind of text you can use, and figure 10 gives you an idea of the interaction flow.

Figure 11: AI-generated asset valuation explanation, after the user clicked on the AI-button “Explain Key Figures”. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a table summarizing the asset valuation, with an AI button “Explain Key Figures” in the table heading. Below the table a section “Explain Key Figures” is shown, with a text explaining how the depreciation is calculated.

Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams

In addition to being able to process To Dos for tasks directly in Microsoft Teams (as I featured in my February blog post), you can now also process To Dos for Business Situations directly in Microsoft Teams.

This means that you get notified in your Teams activity feed about new Business Situations, and you can process Business Situations in place, without having to leave Teams, as you can see in Figure 12.

Figure 12: To Dos for Business Situations are available via Activities in Microsoft Teams. Alt Text: Two screenshots are shown, the top one shows an row of Situation cards in My Home, the bottom one shows the Activity view in Teams, with the activity “Situations in SAP S/4HANA” and sub-text “There are 9 situations for you” selected on the left, and the right two thirds of the screen showing a list with the same situations as shown in My Home.

To enable this, you need to install the SAP S/4HANA for Microsoft Teams app.

For further information:

  • Video: To Dos in Microsoft Teams (1:00)
  • Documentation: Integrating Microsoft Teams.

 

UX Improvements in Details

The details matter for a great user experience, so we continue to gather user feedback and work on improving these details, which though relatively small can have a big impact on user satisfaction. Let’s have a look at the highlights of what we are improving with the 2508 release.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time – magic!

Figure 13: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 13. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 14 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The “Threshold” determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the “Scroll Threshold” determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 14: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “Configure Table” with two new fields “Threshold”, being edited with the value 3000, and “Scroll Threshold”, containing the value 300.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 15, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry “1710 (BestRun US)”, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is “BestRun US”. In the popover “Sort By” section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 15: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over “Column Settings” with two sections “Sort By” and “Group By”. The “Sort By” section has two lines, “Company Code” and “Company Name”, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing “no sorting”, “ascending”, “descending”.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 16), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 16: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “View Settings” containing tabs “Columns”, “Sort”, “Filter”, and a pop-over “Filters” with two options “Hide descriptions” (selected) and “Hide Unselected” (deselected) . “Columns” is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is “Company Code”, followed by “Created On” – i.e. the description column “Company Name” is not listed next to the “Company Code”.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example “1710 (BestRun US)” as shown in Figure 15. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example “US Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)” as shown in Figure 1.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Table Grouping and/or “Show more per row” State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if “show more per row” was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse – but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting “Keyboard Shortcuts” in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 17 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 18.

Figure 17: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Generic Keyboard Interactions”.

Figure 18: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Journal Entries (43,854)”. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using “Cmd + D” to delete.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list, have a look at the What’s New Viewer:

  • UX in What’s New Viewer for  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

Continue Reading with an overview of new UX Innovations for Beta Testing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

entry.title: Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release
entry.content:
Keeping business users informed about system and company news is essential for organizational success. When users are aware of changes that could impact their daily tasks, they can make better decisions, adapt more quickly, and boost overall productivity. Staying up to date—especially with updates on processes, departments, or system changes—helps eliminate confusion and ensures alignment across teams.  

While our existing news feed provides valuable updates on SAP system changes, we’ve listened closely to customer feedback and enhanced communication and user experience on My Home even further. In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, we now offer the ability to customize and manage the My Home news feed through the new Manage News application.

Manage News Application

 

Introducing the Manage News Application 

The Manage News application empowers news administrators to deliver timely, targeted information updates directly to business users via a centralized news feed. 

Key capabilities for news administrators include: 

  • Create, manage, and publish news articles: Administrators can compose news posts to be displayed on My Home, controlling the flow of critical company and system updates. 
  • Control visibility and importance: News items can be marked as critical, ensuring essential information is highlighted and receives appropriate attention from business users. 
  • Plan and schedule communications: Administrators can organize when specific news should be published, enabling timely and organized delivery of updates. 
  • Language adaptation: Messages can be tailored in all company-supported languages, ensuring effective communication across diverse user groups. 
  • Targeted audience assignment: News can be assigned to specific App Transaction codes, so only users with access to the corresponding Fiori apps or transaction codes will see relevant news items. 
  • Organize news by groups or categories: News articles can be grouped into categories such as Finance or Human Resources, making it easy for users to find pertinent information. 
  • Visual enhancements: Administrators can upload images aligned with news topics to make posts more engaging and visually informative. 

News article creation in Manage News Application

 

What Business Users Will Experience 

The My Home news feed now displays articles created by news administrators, neatly organized into designated categories. Critical updates are clearly marked with an eye-catching critical marker to ensure users notice and prioritize these messages. 

This personalized news feature centralizes essential communications in one place, tailored to the needs of each user based on their system app access. By delivering relevant, timely information directly to business users, organizations can foster a more informed and agile workforce. 

 Critical News displayed in My Home News Feed 

Critical News Article in My Home News dialog

 

Benefits for Your Organization 

With the Manage News application, administrators can tailor the news feed to reflect the specific needs of your company or organization, enabling more effective communication with business users. This streamlined and targeted approach to information sharing helps: 

  • Improve user awareness and decision-making 
  • Minimize confusion and misalignment across teams 
  • Increase adaptability to system or process changes 
  • Enhance overall company performance 

 

Prerequisites 

To access the Manage News application users or administrators will have to be assigned to the SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_MNG_PC business catalogue. For business users to view the news feed on My Home they will have to be assigned SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC catalogue. The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE role will already have SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC business catalogue assigned. With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, news maintained in the Manage News application will be displayed by default for all customers who have not configured a RSS feed or SAP Custom System News. To display the news from the Manage News application the 'Manage News App' setting needs to be enabled via UI Adaptation mode (Adapt UI in the User Actions menu). Users or administrator must have the catalog SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLEX attached to their role to access the UI Adaptation key user capabilities. 

My Home UI Adaptation Mode News Feed Settings

 

We’re excited to bring this powerful new communication feature to you with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release and look forward to seeing how it helps your business stay connected and informed. 

If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality. 

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/public-cloud-means-continuous-innovation-and-continuous-learning-new-user/ba-p/14017362 

(Open to SAP Cloud ERP customers, including partners running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.) 

Caroline Welsh, and Suneet Agarwal  on behalf of the SAP UX Foundations responsible for My Home in SAP S/4HANA.

entry.title: How to Design Low-Fidelity Dashboards with the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit
entry.content:
Focus of this blog:

  • Intro
  • How the library is set up
  • How to get the library
  • How to use the library
  • How to work efficiently with the library
  • Essential Ressources

 

Intro

Effective dashboard design begins with user research. Gathering and understanding the necessary insights of your end-users' needs and requirements ensures high-quality experience. Jumping straight into creating high-fidelity mockups or even building dashboards directly in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories can create unnecessary distraction and slow down your design process.

👉  Learn how to build better dashboards here.

Instead, start with scribbles and rough sketches. Early in the process, low-fidelity mockups help you explore ideas quickly, collect feedback, and align on structure and meaningful insights before refining visual details.

That’s why we created the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit for Figma. It helps you transform your ideas seamlessly into digital low-fidelity designs.

The library offers basic layouts and provides components to help you design and iterate quickly, without distraction, ensuring you can focus on what matters: content, flow, and meaningful Insights. It helps you to speed up your design process, share clear ideas, review them with your team, and get feedback from stakeholders.

 

 

How the library is set up

The library consists of three pages, which allows for easy navigation and usage.

The first page, “📓 Cover“, is a library overview that includes a cover, a version history and slides explaining the purpose and usage of the library.

Cover page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

The second page, “✏️ Analytical Pages”, provides dashboard templates. Depending on the purpose of your dashboard, you can choose to use different BI page types, or start with an empty page to design your dashboard from scratch.

Second page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

The third page, “✏️ Components”, contains all other assets: UI elements and controls, containers and different chart types available in SAP Analytics Cloud stories.

Third page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

 

How to get the library

You can easily download the library from GitHub and import it into Figma.

👉  Navigate to the SAC Fiori Horizon Theme folder on GitHub.

Open the file "External_SAC_Dashboard_Schematics_UI_Kit.fig".

Overview of our GitHub folder structure

Click the Download button to save the file.

Placement of the download button on GitHub

Open the downloaded file in Figma. Choose a destination folder, and you're ready to go.

Overview of the import dialogs in Figma

 

 

How to use the library

We recommend publishing the library internally in your company's Figma space after importing the file to make use of Figma’s Library functionality. This means, that based on your settings, your direct team or your whole organization can access the library through the asset panel, enabling smooth collaboration and consistent usage across your design teams.

To publish a library, open the File Settings, navigate to “Library” and click on “Publish Library...”. Select the components you want to publish and specify who can access the library. Click on "Publish" and it's done.

Note: This option won't work if the file has been imported into your Drafts.

File options dropdown menu in Figma

 

Now you can add the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit to your files through the libraries dialog and access all components directly from the assets panel.

If you don’t want to publish the library internally, you can simply copy and paste the components into your own design files or use them as local assets.

 

 

How to work efficiently with the library

To get started, we’ve created a short introduction video that demonstrates how to build a dashboard using the library.

 

 

You can follow one of two possible workflows:

1. Start with an analytical page type

Open a new file and navigate to the assets panel. Drag an instance into your canvas, e.g. a "Monitoring Page".

In the design panel, you can see the different options you have for each instance. The "Monitoring Page" can use the visual type “Placeholder” (default) or “Content”. Switching to “Content” will present basic charts.

Screenshot of the "Monitoring Page" with the "Visual Type" option set to "Placeholder".

 

Most components are nested within each other. This means you can simply select individual parts of an instance to get additional options in the design panel. This makes it easy to adjust the layout to fit your specific needs.

Screenshot of the "Sticky Header" instance in Figma, with its editable options visible in the design panel.

 

 

2. Start from scratch

Open a new file and either create a new frame or navigate to the assets panel to drag an "Empty Page" into your canvas. If you use the "Empty Page", you can detach the instance to freely use and customize the frame.

Screenshot of the "Empty Page" in Figma with the context menu open and the cursor hovering over the "Detach instance" option.

 

Browse or search for the containers you want to use, e.g. a header and multiple panels or cards, and drag them into your frame.

Screenshot of a new dashboard layout in Figma with one panel selected, showing its editable options in the design panel.

 

Set "Visual Type" to “Content” to show charts.

Screenshot of a dashboard with the "Visual Type" menu open and the cursor hovering over the "Content" option.

 

 

 

Feel free to share any feedback, ideas, questions, or requests regarding our SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit in the comments below.

And check out our Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series that was created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 3: Beta AI Innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
This third post in my series gives an overview of the very latest user experience innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, which are so new that they are only released for customers to try them out via beta testing. They are all AI-related, for My Home, for working with SAP Fiori elements based applications, as well as for some individual application use cases.

In case you missed them, Part 2 covers the generally available UX innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, and Part 1 explains how users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can query SAP Analytics Cloud directly via Joule, as well as providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services.

This post covers these innovations for:

My Home

  • AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home.
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications.

SAP Fiori elements based applications

  • AI-assisted easy fill.
  • AI-assisted error explanation.

Individual application uses cases

  • AI-assisted payment exception analysis.
  • Accounting accruals agent.

If you want to try out these features as beta testers, then sign-up for beta testing here:

  • Q3/25: Latest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

Find out more about beta programs and how to Get Involved Early with SAP innovations in general.

 

My Home UX Innovations

AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home

With this feature, you can now get details of a Business Situation shown directly in place on My Home, and even initiate quick actions or make changes to business data there. This is achieved by expanding the Situation card on My Home when you click on it, as you can see in Figure 1, or in action in this video:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:00 min.)

Figure 1: Beta: AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home. Alt Text: An image with two screenshots: the upper one shows the top part of My Home showing three Situation cards in the To-Dos section. One titled “This sales quotation is about to expire” is highlighted and linked with an arrow to an expanded card shown in the second screenshot – the card is taller and wider, contains a summary on the left with three action buttons “Change Validity”, “Reject All Items”, “Close Situation”, and more details on the right.

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications

So far, as I outlined in Part 2, you can use natural language and AI to personalize your My Home by adding Insights Cards. Now, with this beta functionality, you can use natural language to find and add applications and insights tiles.

If you have the functionality activated in your system, you’ll see the AI button “Add Content” in the salutation bar at the top of My Home, as shown at the top of Figure 2. Clicking on this brings a pop-over with the option to add Insights Cards or, as shown, Apps & Insights Tiles. By describing what you want to do, the system will propose suitable applications and Insights Tiles. If you select them and click “Add”, they will be added, either as an entry in your Apps Favorites section, or in the Insights Tiles section. Figure 2 shows these main steps.

Figure 2: Beta: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications. Alt Text: The image shows three screenshots: at the top an extract of My Home showing the blue salutation bar, with an AI button “Add Content” on the right. An arrow has been added linking it to the second screenshot, where a popover “Add Content” is shown, where the user has entered “I want to monitor sales orders what app should I use to do this”, and two of four results are listed and visualized: “Track Sales Orders” and “Manage Sales Orders” (shown as an insight tile). Below that a screenshot of the outcome in My Home: the former is added to Apps Favorites, the latter to Insights Tiles.

 Watch a demo:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:11 min.)

 For a summary of all the news for My Home, both generally available and for beta-testing, read this blog post:

  • My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?

 

AI UX Innovations for Applications based on SAP Fiori elements

AI-Assisted Easy Fill

Users often receive requests via e-mails or chats to change data in the system. This new feature makes it much easier to update the fields in the various sections of an object page based on SAP Fiori elements, such as a sales order. Instead of manually scanning the e-mail and navigating to the relevant sections and fields in the object page, you can just paste the text into Easy Fill and it will automatically identify the correct fields to update, with proposals for the correct entries.

The power of AI means that the new values do not have to be exactly contained in the text. Figure 3 shows an example, where the new address is given without actually mentioning the name of the city, only the street and post code, along with an abbreviation for the state and country (“BW DE”). As you can see, the proposed new values are correct, despite this missing or abbreviated information.

Figure 3: Beta: AI-Assisted Easy Fill for SAP Fiori elements based applications. Alt-Text: A screenshot showing an Easy Fill pop-over, with a text entry field on the left with text from a customer e-mail informing about a change of name and address for their store, and on the left showing the “Filled Fields”, a list of seven fields for which new values are proposed.

Watch a demo:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Easy Fill of SAP Fiori Elements-Based Applications in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:15 min.)

Note that this feature is only available for applications based on SAP Fiori elements.

AI-Assisted Error Explanation

We started beta testing for this with the 2502 release, and have decided to continue with beta testing in this 2508 release. The explanation I gave in my February blog post continues to apply:

New users who are unfamiliar with the system may find that the short error messages give too little information for them to fully understand the issue, and what to do about it. The AI-Assisted Error Explanation (beta) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition summarizes information which explains the error and provide a recommendation for how to resolve it. Figure 8 shows an example where a user has entered a Sold-to-Party ID which does not exist in the system.

Note that this feature is also only available for applications based on SAP Fiori elements.

Figure 4: Beta: AI-Assisted Error Explanation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502. ALT Text: On the left part of a data entry screen is shown, with the field “Sold-to Party containing “ABC” marked red and below that a  popover with an error message “No customer master record exists for sold-to-party ABC”, and in the text line below that the AI icon followed by “Generate Explanation”. A fat arrow leads from this text to the image on the right, which indicates what happens when you click on this text: you get a popover with an short Explanation section and a longer Resolution section with numbered actions.

If you want a summary of the latest such generic AI-assisted features, both generally available and for beta-testing, with some different examples, have a look at this blog post:

  • Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

AI Innovations in Individual Application Use Cases

AI-Assisted Payment Exception Analysis

Most payments of invoices from vendors are automated, but sometimes data is missing or incorrect so that an automatic payment fails. These issues are collected in error logs, and one of the more tedious tasks of Accounts Payable Accountant is to scan through these error logs, understand what went wrong and why, and then fix it.

With AI-assisted payment exception analysis, we make this task much easier and less tedious: users can choose an entry in the error log and simply click on the AI button “Analyze Exception”. The system then provide an analysis, a recommended resolution in natural language, as well as a links to a selection of the most relevant log entries. If a user wants all the relevant logs, they are just one click away. Figure 5 shows what this looks like:

Figure 5: Beta: AI-assisted payment exception analysis. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Revise Payment Proposals applicatin, showing a list of payment exceptions grouped by Error ID. Four error IDs are listed, covering 419 exceptions. One is expanded and has one exception listed in the row below. The main part of the image is a pop-over “Exception Analysis and Resolution”, with natural language explanations in sections “Analysis” and “Resolution” and a section “Logs” with a list of selected logs, and a button to select “All Logs”.

Alternatively, watch this:

  • Video: AI-assisted payment exception analysis (1:20 min.)

Accounting Accruals Agent

An accrual is an accounting entry which represents revenue which has been earned or expenses which have incurred but for which no payment has yet been made. That way, when looking at a particular period such as a quarter or a month, accountants get a more accurate picture of a company’s financial position. For example, if a service was delivered, but not paid for within the period, having the accrual means that the cost of delivering the service and the revenue associated with it both appear in the summary for the period.

Calculating accruals and deferrals is often time very time consuming. It can also require estimates based on historical data, if for example invoices have not yet been created, or payment amounts can be reduced if payments are made quickly in the future.

The new accounting accruals agent can significantly speed this up, potentially reducing the time spent on these activities by 80%! This frees up accountants to work on more value-adding activities, such as analysis. As you can see in Figure 6, the agent creates a list of accrual proposals. For each proposal, you can details on the recommendation, including an explanation for the basis of the recommendation.

Figure 6: Beta: Accrual Proposals made by the accounting accruals agent. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Accrual Proposals applications, showing a list of six accrual proposals on the left. The details of the one selected are shown on the right, showing the recommended accrual amount, the proposed line items and a section “Basis of AI Recommendation” with a natural language explanation along with a bar chart and a forecast line for the trend per month.

Watch this video to find out more:

  • Video: Accounting Accruals Agent (1:36 min.)
