This fourth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP SuccessFactors. It covers Joule and many AI-based UX innovations along with enhanced user experiences. By following the career of Jon, who starts by applying for a job and then grows within the company, you can see how our latest user experience innovations help business users (employees and managers), work more effectively.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Also, if you missed it, do have a look at the many UX innovations which already came out end of last year with the SAP SuccessFactors 2H2024 release:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 3: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More).

The 1H2025 release comes with a large number of UX innovations across the whole portfolio. In the following sections, I’ll summarize the main highlights by following the career of Jon, and showing how the new AI-powered UX innovations help:

  • Jon find the right job with the help of the new guided application experience.
  • Managers move through the hiring process more efficiently, rating skills and competencies of candidates with Joule, and getting AI-assisted interview insights.
  • Jon understand the main features available to him in his employee HR applications.
  • Jon get an easy-to-understand overview of his benefits and payroll.
  • Jon use natural language with Joule to get questions answered and detailed information about pay statements, not only from at his desk but also via mobile phone.
  • Jon learn more, with learning overview and skilled-based learning recommendations.
  • Jon and his manager to manage goals and performance reviews, with AI-insights making his manager’s job a lot easier.

One more innovation is the new alumni experience, for departing and departed employees, helping them to

  • Manage personal information and access important documents during and after the off-boarding process.

To get the complete picture of all the new SuccessFactors innovations, have a look at the links in the “Further Information “ section towards the end of this post.

 

Find the Right Job With New Guided Application Experience

Jon is applying for a job at a company which uses SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, and finds the whole process very intuitive, thanks to the new guided application experience, as well as the further enhancements in the reimagined candidate experience.

Figure 1 shows the new guided application experience. This attractive UI guides applicants through the required steps, with AI-assistance provided along the way. For example, Figure 1 shows the AI button “Suggest Skills”, which can help candidates when listing their own skills by indicating other skills which they may also have but did not consider mentioning.

Figure 1: Guided job application experience with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A screenshot of a six-step guided activity, with the six steps running horizontally across the top of the screen: “Getting Started”, “Profile”, “Skills Information”, “Employment”, “Education”, “Review”. The screen shows “Skills Information”, with ten skills already selected, a search field for adding a skill and an AI “Suggest Skills” button.

Once Jon has gone through the guided steps, he can use the updated and refreshed applications dashboard that gives an overview of his applications with easy access to post-application steps, and to completed and in-progress applications. If Jon wants to review his candidate profile and make adjustments, this is also easier now with the refreshed candidate profile. See examples of these, and more, here:

  • Blog post: 1H 2025: Explore the Reimagined Candidate Experience and New AI-Assisted Capabilities in Recruiting.
  • Documentation: The Reimagined Candidate Experience.

 

Joule and AI-Assisted Interview Insights Help Managers Recruit

Providing Interview Feedback with Joule

Once the interview has taken place, each interviewer needs to summarize their feedback on the candidates, such as Jon. This can now be done easily using Joule and natural language, where you can say who you want to give feedback for and assing the ratings all in one go, as you can see in Figure 2.

Figure 2: Providing interview feedback with Joule. Alt Text: An image of Joule showing a chat, with the first entry by the user being “Mike Wang”, followed by a text asking the user to provide feedback for him, explaining the scale 1 to 5 and providing a text for copying into the chat listing the five areas to rate, and a line for overall comment and one for recommendation. The user has copied the text into their response and added the ratings, comment and recommendation (“yes”). 

AI-Assisted Interview Insights

When multiple interviewers are involved, the recruiting manager needs to consolidate the feedback from all of them, based on their ratings of competencies as well as individual remarks. This is where the AI-assisted interview insights comes in handy: by clicking on the AI “generate” button, the manager gets a natural language summary of the interviewer’s feedback on the candidate Jon. This is provided in sections Overview, Strengths, Concerns, Interviewer’s Overall Feedback, with a separate section Data Referenced that provides an overview of the inputs used to create the AI-assisted insights. Figure 3 shows an example, and Figure 4 shows it in action.

Not only does this help the manager save time and be more efficient, it also helps her be more effective: the feedback across multiple candidates is consolidated consistently, ensuring that all aspects of a candidate’s interview feedback are consolidated and uniformly presented. Furthermore, key insights are highlighted.

Figure 3: AI-assisted interview insights with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a pop-over with interview insights in natural langauge, in sections “Overview”, “Strengths”, “Concerns”, and “Interviewer’s Overall Feedback”. Bottom right has an AI button “Regenerate” and a button “Close”.

Figure 4: AI-assisted interview insights in action with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A short video (GIF) showing a user press the AI button “Generate” and showing the resulting insights, similar to what is shown in Figure 3.

Find out more:

  • 1H 2025: Revolutionizing Hiring Decisions with AI Interview Feedback Insights in SAP SF Recruiting.
  • Documentation: AI-Assisted Interview Feedback Insights.

 

Onboarding Made Easy with WalkMe

Jon got the job, and getting started is made easy for him with the onboarding checklist I featured in my February blog post. Now, when he starts using SAP SuccessFactors for the first time, to get some of his on-boarding tasks done, he gets built-in guidance via WalkMe, which explains applications step by step.

Figure 5 shows an example for when Jon opens up the Employee Profile, he gets an explanation about the purpose of the Profile Preview. Clicking on “Next” takes him to a brief explanation of the “Spotlight”.

Figure 5: An example of WalkMe providing guidance for SAP SuccessFactors users: first explaining the People Profile (upper image), then explaining the Spotlight (lower image). Alt Text: The upper image shows the People Profile for a user, with contact details on the left and cards for Skills, Competencies, Mentoring, Organization, About Me Video, Upcoming Absence on the right. A pop-over hovers above the list on the left with an explanation of the purpose of the People Profile and two buttons “Next” and greyed-out “Back”.

Easy-to-Understand Overview of Benefits and Payroll

Now that Jon is more familiar with SAP SuccessFactors, and has been on the job for a while, he’d like to get an overview of the various benefits he has enrolled in, along with details of his payroll, such as his pay statement along with pay related information. This is now easy with the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, which provides quick access to the various parts of your benefits (Figure 6) and payroll information (Figure 7). These pages list all the relevant parts, with direct links for more information on each of them.

Figure 7: Payroll information in the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. Alt Text: Screenshot of People Profile with the list of sections on the left, “Payroll” selected. On the right one card “Payroll” is shown, with a title “Payroll Information (1 of 3)” and a greyed out left-arrow button and a right-arrow button above a list of items and links.

Have a look at all the enhancements to People Profile in this video, or read about them in this blog post:

  • Video: 1H2025 release highlights – people profile (32 seconds)
  • First Half 2025 Release: What’s New in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central?

Understand Pay Statements with Natural Language via Joule – also Mobile

Jon has used Joule from his browser to answer various HR questions, as well as for creating leave requests. Now, he can use Joule on the go with the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app – as I explained in my Part 1 blog post.

Jon had a look at his pay statement, via the enhanced People Profile we just talked about, and wasn’t quite sure whether he understood how it all fits together (something probably familiar to most people starting out in a job).  Fortunately, he can simply ask Joule to get a natural language explanation of the pay statement, as you can see in Figure 8.

Figure 8: Using Joule to explain your pay statement. Alt Text: An image of Joule showing a chat, with the first entry by the user being “Explain my pay”, followed by a text explaining the current month’s payslip in four sections “Gross Pay”, “Deductions”, “Net Pay” and “Employer Contributions”, and a reminder to check your payslip regularly to ensure tax code and other details are correct.

In figure 8, he simply asked “Explain my pay” and already got a concise summary  in natural language. He started asking “Why are my deductions so high?”. If you want to see how Joule responds to that, and more, watch:

  • Video: 1H2025 release highlights – explain my pay with Joule (35 seconds)

 

Learning Overview and Skill-Based Recommendations

Learning and Development in Enhanced People Profile

Jon is keen to progress in his career and learn more. The enhanced People Profile now includes a “Learning and Development” overview, as shown in Figure 9. Jon gets an overview of his development goals, assignments from the opportunity marketplace, learning history, and required learning, with links to more information and actions.

Figure 9: Learning and development information in the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. Alt Text: Screenshot of People Profile with the list of sections on the left, “Learning and Development” selected. On the right four cards are shown: Development Goals, Opportunity Marketplace Assignments, Learning History, Required Learning. Each has a list of items each with links, and a card-specific link at the bottom to go the application for the card’s topic.

Skill-Based Learning Recommendations

Based on Jon’s skills and his respective proficiency levels, Jon can now look at a particular skill in the Growth Portfolio which he would like to develop further, and get a learning recommendation from SAP SuccessFactors in the “Opportunities to Grow” section. Get a 30-second glimpse of this at 1:59 in this video:

  • Video: SAP SuccessFactors 1H 2025 Release Highlights.

 

Managing Goals and Performance Reviews

Towards the end of the year, it’s time for performance reviews and setting up goals for the next year. With the 1H2025 release, we are introducing a brand new user experience for doing this, with a new UI and several AI-assisted capabilities to help Jon and his manager get this done efficiently with good outcomes.

Figure 10 shows the new UI for managing performance, where you can see your goals, your skills, your ratings and your manager’s rating along with ratings from others.

Figure 10: The new performance form experience in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals. Alt Text: Screenshot of the new form for performance, with the left two-thirds starting with a section for generating AI-powered insights, then “Your Goals” and “Your Skills” as lists with a slider for each entry depicting the rating, columns for employee rating, gap, weight and comment. The goal “Increase sales by $100 million” has been selected. On the right details of the selected goal are shown, with sections “Rating and Comment”, “Ratings from Others” and “Linked Activity (2)”.

Jon’s manager finds it easier to craft helpful feedback by using the following new AI-assisted features:

  • AI-assisted comments, which uses the AI-writing assistant in order to help formulate comments.  (The AI writing assistant was first introduced a year ago, see my blog post from last summer).
  • AI-assisted feedback in performance reviews, which integrates rating context as well as user input to create recommendations for feedback texts.

To see the above in action, watch this:

  • Video: 1H 2025 release highlights - revamped performance form with AI (39 seconds).

Jon himself benefits from the new AI-based sentiment analysis for 360-degree reviews, shown in Figure 11. With this, he can quickly identify positive, negative or mixed feedback, as well as seeing which areas need improvement, thus aiding him in developing as a professional.

Figure 11: AI-based sentiment analysis for 360-degree reviews in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Detailed 360 Report in the background showing partly covered horizontal bar charts for ratings from Manager, Self, Direct Report/Peer/Other, All Except Self and All. The center contains a pop-over “Communicating Effectively – Comments” showing two anonymous comments, the first one labelled “positive”, the second one “mixed”.

 To find out more about all the exciting innovations in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, including the ones just mentioned, look at this blog post:

  • First Half 2025 Release: What is New for SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals?

 

AI-Assisted Offboarding and New Alumni Experience

With this release, we provide AI-assistance to employees who are departing, via AI-assisted offboarding through Joule. This helps employees complete their tasks, providing them with a well-structured offboarding experience.

The new alumni experience goes one important step further, by giving ex-employees access to personal information, documents and resources – and hence a much better overall user experience than before. Figure 12 shows the home page for alumni, giving them direct access to pay statements, profile, documents and personal information. They also get access to payroll and tax-related documents.

Figure 12: The new alumni home page in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding. Alt Text: Image of the home page with a banner across the whole top with the text “Good Morning” , below that a section “Quick Action” with tiles for seven actions, such as “View My Pay Statement”, “View Company Documents”, and a section “Organizational Updates” with four cards with news for alumni.

Get more information here:

  • Video: 1H 2025 release highlights - alumni experience (34 seconds).
  • 1H 2025: Alumni, AI-Assisted Offboarding & Mass Initiation in Onboarding.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 5: SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
This fifth post in my series gives an overview of latest UX innovations in SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass, products for managing your spend (procurement) and external workforce. For SAP Ariba: Joule is now available for selected products, on-boarding guidance is provided by WalkMe, and we have some additional AI-assistance in SAP Ariba Category Management, amongst other enhancements. For SAP Fieldglass, Joule is now available too, and the SOW (Statement of Work) dashboard can now be adapted per user role, ensuring that users see what fits best for them. Also, you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

 

SAP Ariba

Here are the recent UX innovations that I have picked:

  • On-boarding guidance via WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform.
  • Joule, our AI copilot, available for selected SAP Ariba products.
  • UX enhancements in Category Management: Supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, plus some more minor enhancements in details.
  • Integration of the SAP User Research Panel into selected products’ built-in user feedback surveys.

On-boarding guidance via WalkMe

When new employees join the procurement team, we now make it easier for them to get up and running with SAP Ariba by providing enhanced step-by-step guidance on how to get typical tasks done in the system. With the 2508 release, we provide WalkMe for the following SAP Ariba products:

  • SAP Ariba Buying
  • SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing
  • SAP Ariba Contracts
  • SAP Ariba Invoice Management
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Risk

WalkMe offers engaging, intuitive, role-based guidance to help user quickly achieve value by minimizing barriers during initial use of the product and creating a great first experience. Figure 1 gives you an idea of what this looks like, showing first the list of activities available for the current user context within SAP Ariba Sourcing, and then an example of one of the guidance steps (the fourth step after the user had selected “Create a guided sourcing project”).

Figure 1: An example of WalkMe for SAP Ariba Sourcing. Alt Text: two cut-outs from screenshots are shown. On the left the WalkMe panel lists two options “Create a sourcing project” and “Create a guided sourcing event”. On the right, the UI for “Create guided sourcing project” is shown with a pop-over explaining the options for a selecting either a “Single event” or a “Full project”, and explaining why the system has pre-selected “Full project”.

In the guided sourcing capability for SAP Ariba Sourcing, Walkthroughs are available for the following tasks:

  • Create a guided sourcing project.
  • Create a guided souring event.
  • Create a guided sourcing event in a project.
  • Invite suppliers.

Check out the video below to see WalkMe in action in guided sourcing, and find out more in the documentation:

  • Video: Explore Guided Sourcing Events with WalkMe (3:35 min.)
  • Documentation: WalkMe Available in SAP Ariba Products.

You can go one step further and provide content tailored to your organization by purchasing WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba Solutions. For more information about WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba, visit the WalkMe home page.

Joule for SAP Ariba

With the 2508 release, Joule, our AI copilot, is now available for:

  • Supplier management.
  • Guided sourcing.
  • Guided buying.

Figure 2 shows an example of what it looks like when you open up Joule in guided buying, where it provides suggestions for what you could ask. These suggestions are clickable, but you can of course type in your text directly.

Figure 2: Joule for guided buying. Alt Text: An image showing Joule after it has been opened for the first time, with the text “Hello Jitesh, How can I guide you?” at the top. The bottom half contains the chat area, with the text “Get started with Joule” followed by a selection of five suggestions as clickable buttons, such as “Approvers of a requisition”, at the very bottom the input field for the user to message Joule is shown.

The currently availabe capabilities are listed in the documentation:

  • Joule Capabilities in Supplier Management.
  • Joule Capabilities in Guided Sourcing.
  • Joule Capabilities in Guided Buying.

Please note that AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it is planned to be made generally available to customers.

UX Enhancements in SAP Ariba Category Management

This section covers UX enhancements for supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, and provides a link to more UX enhancements in detail.

Supplier Preferencing

When buying from various suppliers, it’s good to know how these suppliers view their relationship with your company. Do they value your custom highly? Or at the opposite extreme, do they see you as a nuisance, i.e. low volume but high effort and hence unprofitable?

Supplier preferencing is an established approach that helps organizations understand how they are perceived by vendors. By leveraging this insight, businesses can strengthen supplier relationships, foster collaboration, and improve supply chain effectiveness.

Supplier preferencing involves evaluating how suppliers view a buying organization based on two key dimensions:

  • Attractiveness of Account: How appealing the buying organization is to the supplier, influenced by factors like reputation, growth potential, and ease of doing business.
  • Relative Value of Business: The monetary value or strategic importance the buying organization's spend brings to the supplier.

Each dimension can be assessed as “high” or “low”, resulting in four possible categories Core, Development, Nuisance and Exploitable, as explained in the

  • Documentation: Supplier Preferencing.

We now provide an intuitive user experience for buyers to apply supplier preferencing very easily, and get an easy to understand overview for each supplier and for each strategy and plan you have created for buying from that supplier. Figure 3 shows an example for a fictitious supplier called SpeedShip, where the outcome of assessments for various strategy and plans are shown.

Figure 3: Supplier preferencing example in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Develop Strategy and Plan app with a pop-over showing with a heading “SpeedShip”, below that four tabs “Overview”, “Performance”, “SWOT” and “Supplier Preferencing” (selected). The pop-over summarizes the supplier as “Nuisance”, with a timestamp of last update, and shows a list of Assessments.

Figure 4 shows an extract of the questionnaire which employees can fill out in order to assess the supplier preference.

Figure 4: Supplier preferencing questionnaire in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Develop Strategy and Plan app with a pop-over showing part of a Supplier Preferencing Assessment Questionnaire, with yes/no questions on the attractiveness of account, such as “Do you see our organization as a potential strategic partner in the industry?”.

Strategy and Plan: Collaborate Externally by Sharing Plans as PDF

Now, Category Managers can share their strategy and plan documents with stakeholders who do not have access to SAP Ariba Category Management, by exporting them to a PDF file.

Stakeholders can review the strategy and plan outside of SAP Ariba Category Management, provide input, follow its direction, and consider it when developing related strategies. The exported file contains the most relevant content from all tools organized into pages so it can also be used as slide deck. Figure 5 shows the export screen, with parts of the first two pages with text summary and details, and Figure 6 shows how charts and tables are nicely presented as a page within the PDF file.

Figure 5: Creating a PDF file for the category strategy and plan within SAP Ariba Category Management, for sharing with stakeholders. Alt Text: A screenshot of the application Category Strategy and Plan with a pop-over for exporting to PDF. The left two thirds of the pop-over shows a preview of the PDF, showing the Strategy and Plan Summary, the right third shows settings for formatting and exporting.

Figure 6: An example PDF page from the exported category strategy and plan for sharing with stakeholders, from SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a pop-over displaying one PDF page with eight cards, the top row of four cards showing charts for Spend, Top Suppliers, Top Regions, Top Subcategories, the bottom row showing lists for the values depicted in the charts.

AI-Assisted Summary for Strategy and Plan

As a category manager, you can use generative AI capabilities for generating a summary in the approval document. AI-enhanced summaries provide a quick overview, highlighting key points without the need to manually review details across all sections of the approval documents. You can refine these summaries and then submit the document for approval. Figure 7 shows an example of such a summary.

Figure 7: AI-generated strategy and plan summary in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Strategy Summary section of the Develop Strategy and Plan application, showing a full width editable text field containing text in sections “Market Dynamics”, “Category Segmentation”, “Cost Structures”. On the right above the section an AI button “Generate” is shown.

Additional enhancements

We have made some additional smaller enhancements to UI details, which improve the user’s experience. They are documented here:

  • SAP Ariba Category Management User Interface Enhancements.

Integration of the SAP User Research Panel

Getting feedback from the actual users of an application is key in order to continuously improve the user experience, and we are intensifying our efforts to reach the real users of our products, rather than the IT departmens who buy them. The SAP User Research Panel gives users the opportunity to sign-up to give feedback to SAP directly. We launched it nearly two years ago, see for example Your voice matters! Join the SAP User Research Panel. Since then many users across all areas have signed up.

We would like to encourage users of SAP Ariba to sign up too, and to make this easier, we have introduced a direct link to it from the user feedback survey. Users of SAP Ariba Category Management and SAP Ariba Supplier Risk occasionally receive a popup with a short survey asking for feedback on the product. Now, at the end of this survey, they are offered a link to sign up to the user resarch panel.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • SAP User Research Panel for SAP Ariba Category Management.
  • SAP User Research Panel for SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Further Information

For an overview of the key innovations with the 2508 release of SAP Ariba, have a look at this blog post:

  • SAP Ariba 2508 Release Key Innovations Preview.

 

SAP Fieldglass

Joule is now available for SAP Fieldglass, the Statement of Work (SOW) dashboard has been enhanced to allow role-specific customized views, and you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

Joule for SAP Fieldglass

Our AI copilot Joule helps users for these specific activities:

  • Selecting job posting templates
  • Selecting statement of work templates
  • Completing work items
  • Viewing quarterly trends
  • Running reports
  • Closing workers
  • Searching help content

As an example of how Joule makes work easier for users, consider finding the right template for a job posting: rather than scanning through available templates, you can just give Joule the position or project, a description, and a few other details, and Joule will provide recommendations for which template to use. Once you have chosen a template, Joule can auto-populate some of the fields, speeding the process up for you.

You can also use Joule for analytical queries: as Joule to show you quarterly trends, and Joule will show you them in the form of graphs embedded within the Joule UI.

Figure 8 shows Joule when first opened in SAP Fieldglass, with hints as clickable buttons for what you can ask for.

Figure 8: Joule in SAP Fieldglass. Alt Text: An image showing Joule after it has been opened for the first time, with the text “Hello Jennifer, How can I guide you?” at the top. The bottom half contains the chat area, with the text “Get started with Joule” followed by a selection of five suggestions as clickable buttons, such as “Create Job Posting”, at the very bottom the input field for the user to message Joule is shown.

Look at the documentation for more information:

  • Joule in SAP Fieldglass

SOW Dashboard with Customizable Views

Effective Statement of Work (SOW) management requires real-time access to critical details like spend activity, service delivery progress, and pending action items. This helps track overall SOW progress, maintain budget control, and enable informed decision-making.  Last year, we introduced the SOW Dashboard, providing a comprehensive real-time view of critical SOW data (see my last year’s blog post).

Users in different business roles need to interact with the SOW, and each role has a unique set of details relevant to them for overseeing the health of the SOW. Now, the SOW dashboard supports customized views based on user roles, which streamlines the information displayed, so that users see only what is most relevant to them. Hence, they get a more focused and efficient experience tailored to their unique needs

Figure 9 shows an example of the SOW Dashboard set up for a user focused on project status and task management. Figure 10 shows an example for a user focused on financials and spend task management.

Figure 9: SAP Fieldglass SOW dashboard customized for users focused on project status and task management. Alt Text: A screenshot of SOW Dashboard showing four cards “SOW Activity Items”, “SOW Line Items”, “SOW Worker Activity Items” and “Upcoming SOW Worker End Dates”. The first three are represented as lists, with color-coded summaries of items that are critical and that have warnings, the fourth shows a 2D visualization with no. of SOW workers on the y-axis and time remaining (days) on the x-axis.

Figure 10: SAP Fieldglass SOW dashboard customized for users focused on financials and spend task management. Alt Text: A screenshot of SOW Dashboard showing four cards “SOW with Largest Budgets”, “Deviations in Actual Spend”, “SOW Spend & Duration Alterts”, and “SOW Revisions”. The first two are represented as charts, the other two as lists.

SOW AI-Assisted Document Extraction

No matter how good the software, having to manually copy data from a document into a system to create a Statement of Work (SOW) does not rank as a great experience for most people! Now, we have significantly improved the user experience by leveraging generative AI to automate a lot of this work.

SAP Fieldglass has integrated SAP Document AI, so that users can automate the extraction and transformation of statement of work content from uploaded documents. This combined AI approach parses the source files, identifies relevant content, and generates a structured, accurate draft statement of work, reducing manual effort while improving data consistency and completeness. Figure 10 shows how users now have the new AI-enabled workflow option for creating a statement of work.

Figure 11: New AI-enabled option for creating a statement of work in SAP Fieldglass. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over “Create Statement of Work” containing two clickable cards: on the left “Standard Workflow” and description “Manually enter and select the details for this Statement of Work”, on the right with an AI icon “Upload Document Workflow” and description “Select a file for AI to read and populate Statement of Work details.”

Once the document has been processed, you can open the drafted statement of work to view the outcome: the AI icon appears next to sections of the document to indicate fields with content extracted using AI.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Documentation: SOW DOX (Document Extraction).

Further Information

Have a look at all the latest updates, month by month, in the

  • What’s New Viewer for SAP Fieldglass.

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Templates in SAP Build Store: A UX-Led Transformation
entry.content:
In early 2024, we discovered something surprising.
The average user spent just 1 minute and 14 seconds in the SAP Build Store. Even more striking: nearly 60% of users left within 15 seconds.

We had invested in pre-designed, ready-to-use solutions, what we call Templates, to accelerate project creation, reduce repetitive tasks, and improve efficiency across SAP Build. But the data told us something else: the feature was practically invisible.

The challenge: our locked treasure

Why was engagement so low? Our research revealed a few key reasons:

  • Terminology like “Store” and “Ready to Use” was confusing
  • The design was outdated and not aligned with SAP’s Fiori guidelines
  • Navigation was weak, leaving users without clear entry points
  • Most users only discovered the feature via a lobby shortcut. Without it, usage dropped dramatically

We had a powerful capability, but no visibility.

The original design: outdated, unclear, and often overlooked

 

Strategic context and research

This redesign was not done in isolation. It aligned with the SAP Build 2025 strategy, which emphasizes predefined processes and best practices to accelerate time to value.

We also reviewed how similar solutions in the market are positioned. A common theme was the strong emphasis on clarity and discoverability, which reinforced the importance of making SAP’s Templates more visible and actionable

 

The big idea: make Templates impossible to ignore

Our guiding principle was simple: Visibility, Clarity, Efficiency.
If users did not see it, they would not use it.

So the mission was twofold:

  1. Make Templates more discoverable, even without shortcuts
  2. Clarify their purpose so users could quickly understand and act

 

Transformation in action

We redesigned the experience with these goals in mind:

  • Consistency: A modern, structured UI aligned with SAP’s design language
  • Navigation: Clearer pathways and filters so users could find relevant templates more easily
  • Cards: A more engaging presentation with images, clearer actions, and hierarchy
  • Clarity: New status badges and improved copy to reduce confusion
  • Guidance: A new dialog to help users understand the difference between Pre-built and Sample templates
  • Terminology: We also introduced several naming changes to reduce confusion and better reflect the feature’s purpose, such as renaming “Store” to Templates, “Ready to Use” to Pre-built, and “Template” to Sample. These adjustments might look small, but they made the feature’s value clearer and easier to understand.

In short, the redesign turned Templates from a hidden corner into a visible, structured, and valuable part of the experience.

The redesigned templates: clearer hierarchy, modern visuals, and consistent actions..

 New Select Template dialog: shown when creating a template that supports both options, helping users choose between Pre-built and Sample with clearer guidance.

 

Testing with users

To validate the new approach, we ran two usability studies:

  • July 2024: with 6 internal SAP colleagues who used the Store daily
  • December 2024: with 5 SAP customers from Vodafone, AIRBUS, Merck, and Twinnings

The feedback was clear:

  • Users finally understood Templates
  • Many admitted they had not known the feature even existed before
  • Excitement grew as they realized Templates could meaningfully support their workflows

One participant summed it up:

“Positive step to move from Store to Template. The UI is much better from the old Store, it is awesome.”

 

The impact

This redesign has not yet been developed, and there is no confirmed timeline for implementation.
But the usability studies made one thing clear:

  • More visibility → more usage
  • More clarity → more efficiency
  • More usability → more business value

 

Key takeaways

  • Do not wait for permission. If something is broken, fix it
  • Business impact and usability go hand in hand
  • Visibility is everything. If users do not see it, they will not use it

This journey reminded me that some of the most impactful UX work is not about adding new features, but about unlocking the hidden value that already exists.

Have you faced a similar challenge in making an important feature more visible and usable? I’d love to hear how you approached it in your product.

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
With the 2508 release, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition continues to embed Artificial Intelligence (AI) at the core of business processes, enabling organizations to work smarter, faster, and with greater confidence. This release brings new AI-assisted capabilities across finance, service, and user experience, empowering employees to make data-driven decisions, reduce manual effort, and focus on higher-value tasks. By combining embedded AI, generative AI, and SAP’s digital assistant Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 sets a new benchmark for intelligent ERP — helping businesses unlock efficiency, innovation, and resilience in the cloud.

 1. Joule Copilots

1.1. Joule for Business

In today's fast-moving digital landscape, businesses need solutions that simplify processes and enhance efficiency. SAP’s Joule for Business stands at the forefront of this transformation. By embedding artificial intelligence directly into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Joule for Business acts as a digital assistant that helps users navigate complex tasks through natural language interaction. With its intuitive design and AI-driven functionality, Joule is not just an assistant—it’s a strategic partner for every business user.

Simplifying Service Contract Management with Joule for Business

For Customer Service Managers, Joule for Business is a game-changer. It allows managers to express their business needs using everyday language, eliminating the need for specialized technical knowledge. Joule then guides users directly to key service management applications, such as the Manage Service Contracts app, Service Management Overview, and Service Contracts Dashboard. The result? Users experience faster navigation, enhanced satisfaction, and improved operational efficiency. By providing seamless access to apps like Mass Processing of Service Contracts and Monitor Auto Renewal Logs, Joule ensures that service contract management becomes a streamlined and user-friendly process.

Streamlining Solution Order Management

Joule for Business also empowers Solution Order Specialists to work more effectively. By understanding business requirements expressed in natural language, Joule navigates users directly to relevant solution order management applications. Key apps such as Solution Orders Overview and Solution Order Profitability are now just a simple command away. This not only saves time but also allows specialists to focus on core activities, driving productivity and enhancing decision-making. Joule thus bridges the gap between user intent and system functionality, transforming solution order management into a more accessible and efficient workflow.

AI-Assisted Sales Order Status Check

Beyond navigation, Joule for Business delivers tangible value in sales operations. With its AI-powered sales order status check, Joule enables businesses to monitor whether sales orders are on track and identify any issues hindering fulfillment. By translating complex fulfillment statuses into plain language, Joule helps users quickly understand bottlenecks, view potential causes, receive resolution suggestions, and seamlessly navigate to the appropriate applications. This functionality improves efficiency and accelerates issue resolution, ensuring that sales processes remain agile and customer-centric.

Read more about Joule: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

 

1.2. Joule for Consultants

Joule for consultants is a conversational AI assistant designed to accelerate SAP project delivery. It achieves this by providing instant guidance grounded in an unmatched knowledge base that is exclusive to SAP and expertly curated. This foundation includes over 200,000 pages of documentation, SAP Notes, Knowledge Base Articles, and terabytes of content from SAP Communities. By tapping into this authoritative source, consultants can get fast, specific answers to complex questions, supporting every phase of a project from discover to run and saving up to 1.5 hours per day.

Beyond its extensive knowledge base, Joule offers powerful SAP-specific code intelligence, built upon a fine-tuned model trained on 250 million lines of ABAP code. This enables consultants to generate code from natural language prompts and significantly reduce the time needed to interpret unfamiliar code by up to 40%. The combination of expert guidance and advanced coding assistance directly impacts project timelines. This acceleration can shorten a typical 12-to-18-month project by up to 14%, translating to a reduction of 1.5 to 2.5 months in the overall project cycle

Read more about Joule for Consultants: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant/sap-consulting-capability.html

 

 1.3. Joule for Developers

Joule for developers is a generative AI assistant embedded within the ABAP development tools to enhance productivity and accelerate the software development lifecycle. Its primary goal is to help developers write, test, and deliver optimized, bug-free code in ABAP Cloud in the shortest possible time. For developers working in environments like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, this translates into a significant reduction in the time and effort required for both writing and testing code, leading to a faster realization of value from their development work.

The assistant provides several key capabilities to achieve this. It offers predictive code completion to generate ABAP code directly in the editor and a Joule chat feature for getting support on development questions using natural language. It can also explain existing development objects or selected lines of code to improve comprehension. To enhance quality, Joule assists in generating and improving ABAP unit tests and can create test classes specifically for CDS entities, helping ensure robust and reliable applications.

 

2. General Availability of AI-assisted Features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

2.1. Simplify Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In the Finance domain, we're enhancing the user experience with AI-powered innovations that transform the way fixed asset data is interpreted and managed. One of the standout features of this release is the introduction of AI-generated explanations for fixed asset key figures. These insights are delivered in natural language and help users clearly understand the origins and calculations behind critical values such as depreciation and net book value. This capability simplifies interpretation, allowing users to grasp financial figures and value changes more quickly, enhancing productivity and reducing the time needed for recurring financial tasks.

Additionally, this innovation comes with AI-assisted asset master data creation, enabling users to enter data using simple conversational commands. This approach decreases the effort and time required for data entry and onboarding while improving accuracy and data governance through intuitive, user-friendly interfaces. SAP Business AI is central to these enhancements, providing detailed explanations and support that facilitate better decision-making and enhance user satisfaction. This release reaffirms SAP's commitment to delivering efficient and user-centric solutions in asset accounting.

 

2.2. Group Reporting: AI-assisted Financial Business Insights for Group Financial Statements Review Booklet

Building on the successful beta release in 2502, predefined AI-assisted business insights—also known as quick actions—are now generally available in the Group Financial Statements Review Booklet. These insights help streamline financial review processes by highlighting key figures, variances, and relevant context in natural language.

The Group Financial Statements Review Booklet, Cost Centers Review Booklet, and Project Financial Booklet – Professional Services now all include AI-powered business insights that enable faster analysis and easier interpretation of financial data. By reducing manual analysis effort and surfacing relevant context automatically, these booklets drive efficiency across various reporting tasks.

 

2.3. AI-assisted processing of incoming quality certificates with SAP Document AI

With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we are excited to introduce SAP Document AI, a groundbreaking innovation that integrates generative AI into quality management processes. This advanced AI feature revolutionizes the handling of incoming quality certificates, significantly enhancing operational efficiency for our customers. By automating the extraction of relevant information from both paper and digital documents and incorporating it into SAP workflows, SAP Document AI streamlines the processing of supplier quality certificates. This leads to substantial reductions in manual efforts, faster processing times, and minimized human errors. As a result, quality technicians are liberated from monotonous tasks, enabling them to concentrate on more strategic and value-adding activities, which, in turn, helps companies expedite stock releases, minimize inspection-related production delays, and enhance overall throughput.

Moreover, SAP Document AI enhances accuracy and reliability by automatically matching quality certificates with system records and updating their status, ensuring that no document is misplaced and compliance is consistently maintained. Additionally, intelligent error handling fortifies system resilience and trust. One of the most compelling features of this solution is its seamless integration into the SAP S/4HANA Cloud experience, offered as a ready-to-use capability that requires no custom development, thereby providing customers with immediate value and swift ROI. As we continue to incorporate AI, data, and automation into our ERP offerings, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition serves as a cornerstone for smarter, more agile operations. The introduction of SAP Document AI exemplifies our commitment to supporting customers in future-proofing their business, driving continuous improvement, and fostering innovation.

 

2.4. Unlock seamless data access with AI-assisted easy enterprise search 

Accessing business data is now even more intuitive with the AI-assisted easy enterprise search, which allows users to search using natural language. Instead of navigating through complex structures, a simple query like “Show me sales orders overall status in process” or “Show me open sales orders that have a net value greater than 100 EUR” provides relevant results instantly.

The system adapts the search results based on the user’s role, ensuring that only the most relevant business objects are presented. This not only improves search accuracy but also accelerates insight extraction—making it easier to act quickly and confidently in a data-rich environment. To enable this feature, select the 'enable AI natural language search' checkbox in the user profile settings.

 

3. Beta Programs of New AI-assisted Features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

3.1. AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release brings a new dimension of intelligence to the user experience with the introduction of the AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home. Currently available in beta testing, this innovative feature simplifies the resolution of business-critical situations by dynamically guiding users through resolution steps—directly from the homepage.

This smart solution leverages generative AI to adapt the user interface in real time, presenting timely insights and suggested actions tailored to the specific business context. Designed to support fast, informed decisions, it transforms traditionally manual and multi-step tasks into a seamless, click-efficient experience.

Accessible from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud homepage, the solution enables situation handling in just a few clicks—significantly reducing the time and effort required to take action. Instead of navigating through multiple screens, users are presented with dynamic cards that surface key information and associated actions. These cards act as entry points to resolve issues directly, eliminating the need for in-depth navigation and enhancing day-to-day productivity.

The substantial benefits of this innovation include saving time, reducing complexity, and improving the quality of decision-making. Generative AI delivers context-aware recommendations and outcomes that are both trustworthy and relevant—built on enterprise-grade intelligence. This intuitive approach allows users to act confidently with minimal effort, ultimately boosting overall efficiency across key operational processes.

To illustrate its impact, consider a common example: a sales representative receives a notification that a sales quotation is about to expire. In a conventional workflow, the user would open the situation, navigate to the quotation, manually edit the details, save the changes, and then return to resolve the situation. With the AI-assisted solution in My Home, these steps are consolidated into a single, streamlined flow—demonstrating how user effort is minimized while responsiveness is maximized.

Join the SAP beta testing for the latest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. For more details, visit the Get Involved Early page to register and contribute to the evolving landscape of AI-driven business processes. 

 

3.2. AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications 

Personalizing the My Home workspace becomes faster and smarter with the new AI-assisted smart personalization feature. Currently in beta testing, it allows users to tailor their applications and insight tiles using natural language.

Applications can be added in just two clicks, including a preview to confirm suitability. This streamlines customization, especially for new or infrequent users, by offering AI-powered suggestions, application descriptions, and live KPIs for dynamic tiles. The experience is intuitive and efficient, ensuring that personalization aligns with users’ daily workflows.

3.3. AI-assisted easy fill 

Also in beta, AI-assisted easy fill reimagines how form fields are completed. Instead of manually searching for and filling out fields, users can enter data via natural language. The system intelligently matches input to the correct fields and provides a clear overview before confirmation.

This innovation saves time, reduces navigation complexity, and increases accuracy in form completion. With automatic field matching and editable previews, easy fill offers a new level of convenience for maintaining business objects efficiently.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 delivers a powerful set of innovations that bridge insight and action with the support of generative AI. 3.4. AI-assisted payment exception analysis

In the Manage Automatic Payments app (App ID: F0770), a new AI capability enhances the process of analyzing payment exceptions after a payment proposal run. This feature not only provides natural language explanations of payment exceptions but also highlights relevant log entries and suggests resolution actions.

This innovation reduces the time spent investigating and resolving issues in payment proposals. By guiding users directly to the root cause and recommended next steps, the process becomes significantly more efficient—improving payment accuracy and minimizing delays in financial operations.

For a deeper understanding of the power of these AI agents, have a look at this longer video:

  • Video: SAP CX AI Toolkit: AI Insights Agents for SAP C4C & Shopping Assistant | Product Inspiration Series (32:21 min.)

SAP Emarsys

AI-Assisted Report Builder using Natural Language

You can now easily create a report using natural language to describe what you are interested in. Figure 3 shows an example of the entry screen. At the bottom you see hints on what kind of queries you can enter.

Figure 3: AI-assisted report builder in SAP Emarsys. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Unlock the Power of Data with the AI-assisted Report Builder” in the middle. At the top a text entry field containing the query “What are the Sent, Delivered, Bounced, Opened, Clicked, Purchased, Unsubscribed, Complained for my Email campaigns in the past month?”, to the right an AI button “Generate Report”. At the bottom of the screen two example queries are listed.

Once you have created the report, you can easily adjust it using a set of convenient filters, such as the date range as well as the list of campaigns and metrics. Watch this video to see it in action:

  • Video: AI-assisted Report Builder (46 seconds).

AI-assisted Product Finder using Natural Language (Pilot)

Pilot customers can now try out the new AI-assisted product finder, which allows users to search for product to add to marketing campaigns using natural language. Figure 4 shows an example of how to enter your search text, see more here:

  • Video: AI-assisted Product Finder (38 seconds).

Figure 4: AI-assisted product finder available to SAP Emarsys pilot customers. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a screen with a left half containing the Product Finder, with a search field containing “Most popular shoes in the last 6 month”, above an empty space with the text “Welcome to Product Finder!” in the middle. The right half shows an image of someone dancing in the sun and an image of a dress, along with some describing text.

Read more about latest SAP Emarsys innovations here:

  • SAP Emarsys Q2 2025 Product Release.
  • SAP Emarsys introduces new generative AI capabilities in June Product Release

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Joule in SAP Sales Cloud

Joule is now available in SAP Sale Cloud Verion 2, helping users get quick insights, for example about an account. As you can see in Figure 5, these insights can be charts as well as text based.

Figure 5: Joule for SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot of Joule showing Customer Account Overview, with the text “Show Key Metrics” entered as chat, below which a card with a vertical stacked bar chart shows credit limit usage (remaining amount and exposure amount), below that a card showing Key Metrics (Activity) and part of a donut chart for Tasks, Phone Calls, Appointments, Visits etc.

Have a deeper look here:

  • Video: Intelligent Selling with Joule in SAP Sales Cloud & SAP S/4HANA Cloud | Product Inspiration Series (16:04 min.)

Sales Order Summary

The Sales Order Summary uses generative AI to summarize key information about the sales order, as well as including information about some changes, for example how the price compares to the original price. Figure 6 shows an example, with the insights shown on the left of the screen.

Figure 6: Sales Order Summary in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a sales order, with the left third showing an overview with AI-generated insights such as “13 days past requested date”, “Overall discount is EUR 808.55”. On the right, the Order Summary tab is shown, with account name, net and gross value, pricing stats, above “Products in Cart (2)” showing a list of two products, followed by the top part of a list of pricing steps.

Learn more here:

  • Documentation: Sales Order Summary.

 

SAP Concur

The new Concur Travel experience makes it much easier to book travel involving multiple bookings, such as a flight plus hotel plus rental car. And if you just need to book one item, you can do that very easily now with the new Booking Agent powered by Joule.

New Concur Travel Experience

When travelling for a few days, one often needs to book more than one item. A typical combination is booking a flight, a hotel and a rental car. Up until now, you have had to book each item separately and take care that the dates and time match. Now, with the new Concur Travel experience, planning and booking is much easier: you can enter the start and end dates for your flight, and the new feature Match Flight Booking is applied to the hotel and car, so that dates and time match automatically.

Figures 7 to 11 show what this looks like: Figure 7 shows the start screen, where you select which items you want to include (flight, hotel, car, train). Figure 8 shows the flight view, where flight dates have been entered. Figure 9 shows the hotel search, with the default selection “Based on flight selection”, and similarly Figure 10 shows the rental car search, with pick-up and return times calculated based on the flight schedule. Figure 11 shows the finalize screen, in this case showing that the flight and hotel has been selected but the rental car is still open.

Figure 7: New Concur Travel experience start screen. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over with a large image of a magnifying glass on a globe, above the text “Start Planning”. Below that four check boxes in a row: Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train, at the bottom “Continue” and “Cancel” buttons.

Figure 8: New Concur Travel experience screen with flight details. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a trip planning for a Trip to Las Vegas. The left third of the screen shows a list with items Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, with Flight selected. Below the list buttons “Add to trip” and “Search”. On the right a selector for round-trip (selected), one-way or multi-city, with fields for from / to locations and a date field for the stard and end date. To the right a button “Time preferences” and a drop-down for selecting “Cabin”.

Figure 9: New Concur Travel experience screen with hotel details. Alt Text: As for Figure 8, but with Hotel selected, and on the right Hotel Search displayed, with the fields for “Hotel, location, or name” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection”.

 Figure 10: New Concur Travel experience screen with rental car details. Alt Text: As for Figure 9, but with Rental Car selected, and on the right Rental Car Search displayed, with the fields for “Pickup” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection” and the field “Drop-off” filled with “Same as pickup”. Pickup Time and Drop-off Time fields have 10:00 AM entered.

Figure 11: New Concur Travel experience finalize screen. Alt Text: Screenshot showing “Trip to Las Vegas” on the left two-thirds, with a card summarizing the flight with United Airlines from San Antonio, TX (SAT) – Las Vegas, NV (LAS) and a card summarizing the hotel Courtyard by Marriott Las Vegas. The right third shows the Estimated Total Cost $2497.85 above a list with the cost of each item (flight, hotel, rental car), and buttons for “Finalize Trip” and “Cancel Trip”, and options to book anything else (Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train).

As you can see in Figure 11, another advantage of the new experience is that you get budget transparency at the trip level. Also, you have flexibility to book parts of the travel now and other parts later.

Technically it supports deep linking, which means that you can send a trip-level link to colleagues which includes all the trip parts, making it easy to coordinate trip planning when travelling with others.

To find out more, have a look at the

  • Documentation: Trip Planning in New Concur Travel.

Booking Agent in Concur Travel

The new Booking Agent lets you use natural language to book business travel which is compliant with company policy and budget constraints as well as taking into account your personal travel preferences.

Figure 12 shows an example where the user has simply stated “I want to book a flight from San Francisco to London on Sept 9th and back on Sept 13th”. The answer shown takes into account the user’s frequent traveler memberships, flight availability and company policies.

Figure 12: New Concur Travel Booking Agent in Joule. Alt Text: A screenshot of Concur Travel with Joule opened on the right, the content is explained in the main text, with the possible flights listed alongside a thumbnail image representing the airline “jetBlue”.

Watch it in action and find out more:

  • Video: Concur Travel – Booking Agent demo (2:33 min.)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Booking Agent.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
entry.content:
This seventh and last post in my series gives an overview innovations in our UI tools and technologies, making it ever easier to design, build and integrate UIs, for both web and mobile applications. For designing apps, web and mobile, we have a new SAP Design System portal and UI Kits in Figma. For developers, we have added further AI assistance, as well as many individual improvements, including support for the latest international accessibility standard WCAG 2.2. Fun fact: SAPUI5 is now used on all 7 continents – yes, Antarctica too! 

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

The above post also gives an update on building your own Joule agents, so I will not cover that here, but rather focus on web and mobile UI development.

 

Design News

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits in Figma

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

Figure 1: The SAP Design System portal start page. Alt Text: Image with header saying “SAP Design System”, with a “See what’s new” button below it, and then four subsections in a horizontal row: SAP Fiori for Web, SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for iOS and SAP’s Digitial Design System. A “Feedback” button is on the bottom right.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

Figure 2: SAP’s UI Kits for Designers in Figma. Alt-Text: The image shows two rows of four cards representing UI Kits: SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for Web, Designing for Performance, SAP Fiori for iOS, SAP Fiori for watchOS, SAP Fiori for Wear OS, SAP S/4HANA for Web, and Accessibility Design Tools. On the very left of the image information about SAP is listed, with links to resources such as www.sap.com/design-system.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite

Consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises. We have identified areas directly relevant to users and plan to introduce a number of design updates in SAP Fiori for web across our suite of products to further increase consistency.

The areas we have redesigned and which we plan to provide across our suite of products this year and next year are:

  • Shell bar (at the top of the user’s screen)
  • Navigation menu: side navigation (see Figure 3 below).
  • User menu
  • Notifications
  • Search in the shell bar

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition already supports the first four of these, you can have a look at them in part 2 of this series, in the section SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad.

As outlined in Part 1, SAP Build Work Zone standard edition also supports side navigation.

Find out more about these design updates here:

  • Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web).

We also provide designers with a refreshed new set of illustrations, to be used for illustrated messages. Figure 3 shows some examples.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing “search”. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

News for Creating Web UIs

Extensibility made easy with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is made much easier since we introduced the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard. The latest update introduces the ability to create an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension.

Figure 4: Creating an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension. Alt Text: Screenshot showing step 1 “Extension” task where users can select from a row of four cards “Custom Field”, “Custom Logic”, “Custom Process” and “User Interface Extension”. The latter has a subtext “Adapt the current application or extend it visually with a new application”. The latter two cards have a link “Manage SAP Build Projects” at the bottom. The bottom right shows two buttons “Next” and “Cancel”.

Learn more here:

  • SAP Build Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter

UI5 linter is the tool of choice to check your UI5 project for using best practices and replacement of deprecated SAPUI5 APIs. With UI5 linter v1.12.0, we are happy to announce the initial version of an autofix feature: Use the "--fix" argument to let UI5 linter apply fixes to your code automatically. Read more about it here:

  • Migrate your code with UI5 linter – Autofix has landed.

Legacy-free version of SAPUI5 available via cloud access

Once you have removed code which uses deprecated SAPUI5 APIs, you can try out the legacy-free version of SAP UI5 in the cloud, which has all deprecated code removed. Discover the benefits and how to try it out in this blog post:

  • Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don’t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging – so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2

SAP Fiori tools – open source, faster app creation, more AI

One of the most powerful recent innovations is the AI-powered project accelerator from SAP Fiori tools, which allows you to create a fully functional app with database tables, CDS-Views, OData service and a Fiori element list report UI based on a sketch of what you want. I introduced this in my Q1 update post from March. This can now be started from Joule in SAP Build Code. Also, it has been further enhanced, and is also available as open source, so that our developer community can make contributions themselves. Find out more here:

  • From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps
  • SAP Fiori Application Generator Available in Open Source

For those of you developing in ABAP, we have introduced the new quick SAP Fiori application generator to create and deploy simple SAP Fiori applications from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse. Have a closer look:

  • Quickly Generate and Deploy SAP Fiori Apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

To get an overview of these plus some additional enhancements, have a look at:

  • SAP Fiori tools 2506 update – Open source, faster app creation, adaptation boost, AI enhancements.

Enhancements for SAP Fiori Elements with OData V4

We are continuously enhancing SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements. I have picked two enhancements to highlight here for developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4, which are covered in the following subsections:

  • Support for inline edit for object pages.
  • Support for the analytical table on the object page.

Support for inline edit for object pages

You can now develop object pages where users can directly edit fields within facets, without having to first press the “Edit” button and go into edit mode. Figure 5 shows an example from a test application.

Figure 5: Inline editing of fields in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of part of an object page “Travel”, which is overall in display mode, but the field “Starting Date” has been selected and is editable, with a new entry made, and “Save” and “Cancel” icons next to the field.

Support for the analytical table on the object page

For applications where users need to be able to analyze the data in a table, for example grouping data and aggregating data, developers should use the analytical table rather than the responsive table.

These tables are often used for the “list” part of an SAP Fiori elements list report, which consists of a list and an object page for the details. Now, developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4 can include an analytical table into one of the facets of an object page. Figure 6 shows an example.

Figure 6: Analytical table in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of an object page with a facet “Journal Entries (4)” which contains an analytical table, where the entries are grouped by “Case Journal Entry”. One of the groups is expanded, showing two lines. Below them the sum of the debit column is shown for the expanded group, and below that for the entire table.

Further Updates for SAPUI5

As I described in part 1 of this series, we have introduced a new option to preview an upcoming SAPUI5 version for SAP Build Work Zone. This capability aims to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

Key users can create consistent text changes with SAPUI5 flexibility. I described this in the context of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in part 2 of this series (section Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column). They can also easily change the labels used, to fit terms established within the company. Read more about this here:

  • How Key Users Create Consistent Text Changes with SAPUI5 Flexibility.

SAPUI5 has reached a new milestone: it is now used on all 7 continents. Yes, we have reached Antarctica!

  • SAPUI5 adoption becoming more universal.

In case you have not updated your system for a while, then be aware that we are removing SAP Fiori themes Belize and Blue Crystal. Also, make sure that you are using the latest browser versions, which may mean ensuring that your users laptops and desktops are using newer operating system versions:

  • Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal
  • Prevent an SAP Fiori / SAPUI5 Downtime — Check Your Browser Strategy Today!

To get a complete overview of all the enhancements in SAPUI5 including SAP Fiori elements, look at the UI5 demo kit. You’ll find some of the enhancements mentioned above listed under version 1.136.

  • What’s New in SAP UI5.

 

News for Mobile Designers and Developers

The main news for mobile designers are the new SAP Design System portal, which covers Android and iOS as well as the latest releases of the mobile Figma design kits for Android, iOS, WatchOs and WearOS.

Figure 7: The Android and iOS pages in the new SAP Design System portal. Alt Text: Both screenshots look the same, except for Android vs iOS text. The top has a “Get Started” section, with a row of cards to navigate to UI Elements, UI Kit, Development Documentation. Below that a “What’s New” section, with information about the latest release “SAP Fiori for Android version 25.8” and “…for iOS…”.

The best place to stay up-to-date with these latest enhancements is the respective What’s New section in the SAP Design System portal:

  • SAP BTP SDK for iOS 25.4: What’s new for SAP Fiori for iOS
  • SAP BTP SDK for Android 25.8 (design preview) and 25.4: What’s new for SAP Fiori for Android

Figure 8 shows two of the many new enhancements: the new illustrations mentioned earlier in the section on web UIs are also available for mobile, both for iOS and Android. The other example shown there is the updated date picker for Android, which now allows users to select date ranges.

Figure 8: On the left, an example of the new illustrated messages for mobile. On the right, date ranges can now be selected in the date picker for Android. Alt Text: The illustrated message is used in a pop-over. The illustration shows a sheet of paper with a tickmark, below that the text “You’re all caught up…” and two buttons “Add Task” and “Remind Me Later”. On the right two date screens are shown for the month of April: the left one has the 8th marked, the right one has the range from 8th to 16th marked.

Developers get new features with the latest releases of the mobile SDKs, as well as the the Mobile Development Kit (MDK) which is integrated into SAP Build Code. Here are links to find out more about them:

  • What’s new in Mobile development kit client 25.6, for example:
    • Support grouping in Object Table Control
    • Donut chart support
    • … and more.
  • Continuous Innovation in Mobile Design & Technology: SAP Fiori for Android and iOS 25.4
  • SAP BTP SDK for iOS: What’s New in 25.08
  • SAP BTP SDK for Android 25.4.0 is now available

 

Final words

As you can see from all seven posts in the series, we continue to progress rapidly with the user experience of our product portfolio, especially with regards to AI-assistance.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

  • www.sap.com/design.
